TI Missing geographic link: minute lady beetles (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae:
   Microweiseinae) from Mount Wilhelm, New Guinea.

AB Lady beetle fauna of the New Guinea has been studied by several
   entomologists but there are still many coccinellid groups that have not
   been recorded from the island yet. Newly collected materials from "Our
   Planet Reviewed - Papua New Guinea" expedition revealed three new
   species belonging to the subfamily Microweiseinae, till now unknown from
   New Guinea. Scymnomorphus bimaculatus sp. nov., S. papuensis sp. nov.,
   and S. kausi sp. nov. are described, and key characters are illustrated.
   A key to Scymnomorphus species of the Australasian Region is provided.

   species (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae).

AB Dianous lilizheni sp. nov., a new species of the Dianous luteoguttatus
   complex from China, is described. Males of D. vorticipennis Puthz, 2005
   and D. depressifrons Puthz, 2016 and the female of D. rimosipennis
   Puthz, 2005 are discovered for the first time. New distributional
   records are reported for D. cruentatus L. Benick, 1942 and D.
   depressifrons Puthz, 2016. A key to species of the Dianous luteoguttatus
   complex is provided.

DT Article
TI New species and first record of Helotrephes from India, and a check-list
   of Indian Helotrephidae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera).
AU Jehamalar, E. Eyarin (jehamalar@gmail.com) 
   Chandra, Kailash
   Zettel, Herbert
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 58
IS 1
PS 243-248
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Helotrephes nainamalaii sp. nov. from Meghalaya, India is described.
   Representatives of Helotrephes are so far known from southern China,
   Southeast Asia and Sundaland. The unexpected first record of Helotrephes
   from India expands their distribution more than 1,000 kilometres
   westward. The new species belongs to the H. australis species-group
   which is widespread in southern China and Southeast Asia. Helotrephes
   nainamalaii sp. nov. can be identified by the presence of a sub-basal
   protrusion on the genal plate, a characteristic apical hook on the
   aedeagus, and peculiarly shaped ventromedian carinae. The description is
   supplemented by a key to the species of the Helotrephes australis
   species-group. Tiphotrephes indicus (Distant, 1910) is recorded from
   Meghalaya for the first time. A check-list of Helotrephidae in India is
   given.
C1 Jehamalar, E. Eyarin; Zool Survey India, Kolkata, W Bengal, 700053,
   India, India.
EM jehamalar@gmail.com
RI CHANDRA, KAILASH/AAU-5395-2020
OI CHANDRA, KAILASH/0000-0001-9076-5442

SN 0374-1036

   Publications; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Helotrephes [India /  / New record]. 
   Helotrephes nainamalaii [Meghalaya /  / New species]. 
   Helotrephidae [Checklists /  / ] [India /  / ]. 
   Tiphotrephes indicus [Meghalaya /  / New record].

TI Four new species and new records of Manota (Diptera: Mycetophilidae)
   from Sulawesi, Indonesia.
AU Hippa, Heikki
   Kurina, Olavi (heikki.hippa@gmail.com) 
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 58
IS 1
PS 249-256
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new Manota species are described from the northern part of
   Sulawesi: M. ashleyi sp. nov., M. axillata sp. nov., M. loriculata sp.
   nov. and M. spathigera sp. nov. New records are given for the following
   species: M. dolichothrix Hippa & Sevcik, 2010 (South Sulawesi), M.
   horrida Hippa, 2006 (North Sulawesi), M. ovata Hippa, 2006 (North
   Sulawesi), M. paulula Hippa & Sevcik, 2013 (North Sulawesi) and M.
   pectinata Hippa, 2006 (South Sulawesi). In addition, M. hamulata
   Colless, 1966 is recorded from Bacan Island, Maluku Utara. The number of
   Oriental Manota species is now set at 102 and the number of species from
   Sulawesi at 14.

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of selected genera of the tribe Opsiini
   (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Deltocephalinae) from the Kingdom of Saudi
   Arabia.
AU El-Sonbati, Saad (anase24@yahoo.com) 
   Wilson, Michael
   Al Dhafer, Hathal
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 58
IS 1
PS 257-266
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The redescriptions of two genera of Opsiini (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae),
   Concavifer Dlabola, 1960 and Phlepsopsius Dlabola, 1979, are given based
   on specimens collected recently in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.
   Concavifer nativus Zhuravlev, 1991 syn. nov., and C. sagittatus
   Emeljanov, 1972 syn. nov. are proposed as new subjective junior synonyms
   of C. marmoratus Dlabola, 1960. Phlepsopsius africanus Abdul-Nour, 2007,
   syn. nov., is proposed as a new subjective junior synonym of P. arabicus
   Dlabola, 1979. The genus Hishimonus Ishihara, 1953 is newly reported for
   the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, represented by the species H. phycitis
   (Distant, 1908). A key is provided to distinguish the species of
   Concavifer.
C1 El-Sonbati, Saad; King Saud Univ, Museum Arthropods, POB 2460, Riyadh,

DT Article
TI Two new species of Heleomyzidae (Diptera) from Czech Republic and
   Crimea.
AU Preisler, Jiri (preisler.blb@seznam.cz) 
   Tkoc, Michal
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 58
IS 1
PS 267-274
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Heleomyzidae are described. Heleomyza kovali sp. nov.
   is described based on material from the Czech Republic and Crimea and
   differs from other European Heleomyza species by the structure of male
   genitalia. Eccoptomera nevrlyi sp. nov. is described based on two males
   from Jeseniky Mts. and Sumava Mts. (Czech Republic) and differs from the
   most similar species, E. ornata Loew, 1862, by the hind femur having a
   distinct subbasal protuberance with a tuft of short setae and by the
   structure of male genitalia. The extreme rarity of both species is
   discussed.
C1 Preisler, Jiri; Vlnarska 692, Liberec, CZ-46001, Czech Republic, Czech
   Republic.
EM preisler.blb@seznam.cz
SC Zoology
SN 0374-1036

   region; Eurasia; Europe

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Heleomyzidae
OR Eccoptomera nevrlyi (Heleomyzidae): [Sp nov, Czech Republic, P. 271].

DT Article
TI A revision of the types of Heteroptera species described by Geza Horvath
   based on specimens from collections of Ladislav Duda and Emil Holub.
AU Kment, Petr (sigara@post.cz) 
   Redei, David
SO Acta Entomologica Musei Nationalis Pragae
VL 58
IS 1
PS 275-295
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A recent cataloguing of the Heteroptera (Hemiptera) types held in the
   collection of National Museum, Prague (NMPC), revealed several specimens
   originating from the collection of Czech collectors Emil Holub and
   Ladislav Duda, being part of the same series as types described by Geza
   Horvath in his paper 'Hemiptera nova africana' and until now believed to
   be deposited exclusively in the Hungarian Natural History Museum,
   Budapest (HNHM). The publication date of that paper is fixed as March
   20, 1893, affecting these taxa: Reduviidae: Co-ranopsis Horvath, 1893,
   Coranopsis vittata Horvath, 1893, Cosmolestes fulvus Horvath, 1893,
   Edocla albipennis Horvath, 1893, Harpactor (Diphymus) dudae Horvath,
   1893, Oncocephalus angustatus Horvath, 1893, Phonoctonus validus
   Horvath, 1893, Reduvius reuteri Horvath, 1893, Staccia inermis Horvath,
   1893; Blissidae: Ischnocoridea Horvath, 1893, Ischnocoridea elegans
   Horvath, 1893; Rhyparochromidae: Aphanus (Graptopeltus) dilutus Horvath,
   1893 (= Naphiellus dilutus (Horvath, 1893)), Pamera bergrothi Horvath,
   1893 (= Horridipamera bergrothi (Horvath, 1893)); Coreidae: Homoeocerus
   fuscicornis Horvath, 1893, Hypselonotus balteatus Horvath, 1893 (=
   Hypselonotus interruptus Hahn, 1833); Plataspidae: Niamia Horvath, 1893,
   Niamia angulosa Horvath, 1893; Scutelleridae: Cantao africanus Horvath,
   1893, Cryptacrus princeps Horvath, 1893 (= Cryptacrus comes comes
   (Fabricius, 1803)), Polytodes Horvath, 1893 (= Polytes Stal, 1867),
   Polytodes ochraceus Horvath, 1893 (= Polytes tigrinus (Vollenhoven,
   1868)); Dinidoridae: Dinidor vicarius Horvath, 1893; Pentatomidae: Caura
   modesta Horvath, 1893, Diploxys (Paracoponia) holubi Horvath, 1893 (=
   Coponia holubi (Horvath, 1893)), Paracoponia Horvath, 1893 (= Coponia
   Stal, 1865), Mecosoma spinosum Horvath, 1893 (= Macrorhaphis acuta
   Dallas, 1851), Menida distanti Horvath, 1893 (= Menida transversa
   transversa (Signoret, 1861)), and Stollia crucifera Horvath, 1893. Only
   the following type specimens bearing Horvath's original type label and
   deposited in HNHM are recognized and their status elucidated: Coranopsis
   vittata (1 syntype), Cosmolestes fulvus (holotype), Edocla albipennis
   (holotype), Harpactor (Diphymus) dudae (1 syntype), Oncocephalus
   angustatus (1 syntype), Reduvius reuteri (1 syntype), Homoeocerus
   fuscicornis (1 syntype), Hypselonotus balteatus (1 syntype), Niamia
   angulosa (1 syntype), Cryptacrus princeps (1 syntype), Polytodes
   ochraceus (holotype), Dinidor vicarius (holotype), Caura modesta
   (lectotype), Diploxys (Paracoponia) holubi (lectotype), and Menida
   distanti (1 syntype). The syntype(s) of Cantao africanus and holotype of
   Stollia crucifera could not be located; a specimen in NMPC presumably
   from the same series is designated here as neotype of Stollia crucifera.
   Based on the examination of the type material the following subjective
   synonymies are proposed: Neotrichedocla quadrisignata (Stal, 1855) =
   Reduvius reuteri Horvath, 1893, confi rmed synonymy; Dinidor
   impicticollis Stal, 1870 = D. vicarius Horvath, 1893, syn. nov.;
   Parantestia (Chromantestia) cincticollis (Schaum, 1853) = Parantestia
   (Chromantestia) modesta (Horvath, 1893), syn. nov. = Parantestia
   (Chromantestia) cincticollis var. bergrothiana Kirkaldy, 1909, syn.
   nov.; Cosmopepla cruciaria Stal, 1872 = Stollia crucifera Horvath, 1893,
   syn. nov. Rhynocoris katangensis Schouteden, 1929 (Reduviidae),
   erroneously considered as
C1 Kment, Petr; Natl Museum, Dept Entomol, Cirkusova 1740, Prague, Horni
   Pocernice, CZ-19300, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.

TI DESCRIPTION OF TWO NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS ALEUROPLEUROCELUS DREWS &
   SAMPSON (HEMIPTERA: ALEYRODIDAE) FROM MEXICO.
AU Angel Sanchez-Flores, Oscar (oscaruaaan@gmail.com) 
   Emilio Carapia-Ruiz, Vicente

VL 34

LA English
U1 0

AB Aleuropleurocelus caudatus Sanchez-Flores and Carapia-Ruiz sp. nov.
   collected in Asuncion Ixtaltepec, Oaxaca from the underside of leaves of
   Coccoloba uvifera, and Aleuropleurocelus bidentatus Sanchez-Flores and
   Carapia-Ruiz sp. nov. collected in Acapulco, Guerrero from the underside
   of leaves of Diospyros acapulcensis subsp. acapulcensis are described

   provided, and differences from other Aleuropleurocelus species are
   discussed.

AN ZOOR15504022883
DT Article
TI ECTOPARASITES ASSOCIATED WITH A GREAT HORNED OWL NESTING (AYES:
   STRIGIDAE) POPULATION IN FRAGMENTED LANDSCAPE OF BAJA CALIFORNIA
   PENINSULA, MEXICO.
AU Bolanos-Garcia, Raquel
   Rodriguez-Estrella, Ricardo (rbolanos@pg.cibnor.mx) 
   Guzman-Cornejo, Carmen
SO Acta Zoologica Mexicana Nueva Serie
VL 34
PS 1-15
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ectoparasites are important in avian host population because they can
   affect health condition, regulate population dynamics and alter
   interspecific competition. Studies of ectoparasites in wild raptors are
   scarce and even few have been made in owls. This is the first study of
   the prevalence and intensity of ectoparasites in Great Horned Owl (Bubo
   virginianus) fledglings. We studied ectoparasites on fledglings from
   nests in a fragmented arid landscape at Baja California peninsula,
   during the breeding seasons of 2015 and 2017. The fledglings of 40 days
   of age were handled and taken from their nests for the collection of
   ectoparasites. A total of 81 epizoic species were collected from 36
   nestlings from 15 nests, distributed in five orders: Diptera (Icosta
   americana); Hemiptera (Cimicidae gen. sp.); Phthiraptera
   (Neohaematopinus sciurinus, Colpocephalum pectinatum); Siphonaptera
   (Orchopea sp.) and Mesostigmata (Ornihtonysus sylviarum). Likewise, one
   species of chewing lice (n=5) (Geomydoecus telli) and one species of
   feather mite (n=7) were also recorded associated with the Great Horned
   Owl. Five species were hematophagous parasites. Louse fly I. americana
   and chewing louse C. pectinatum showed the highest levels of prevalence
   (26.5% and 20.6% respectively), while the hematophagous feather mite
   Ornihtonysus silviarum presented the higher mean intensity in only one
   nest (15.5). The flea Orchopea sp. and the chewing louse G. telli and
   sucking louse N sciurinus exhibited the lowest values of prevalence and
   mean intensity; these species have been recorded in association mainly
   with rodents, so probably they could have been transmitted to the owls
   when they were captured as preys and taken into their nest. Additionally
   a bug (Cimicidae gen. sp.) was found in one host. Colpocephalum
   pectinatum is the first recorded from Great Horned owl, such as new
   host. The abundance of ectoparasites in one owl nest was independent of
   their abundance in neighbor nests (Moran's I = 0.010; z = 0.16, P >
   0.05). We discuss the implications of ectoparasitism for a Great Horned
   owl population in fragmented habitat of the Baja California arid desert.
C1 Rodriguez-Estrella, Ricardo; Ctr Invest Biol Noroeste, Lab Spatial Ecol
   & Conservat, La Paz, Bcs, Mexico, Mexico.
EM rbolanos@pg.cibnor.mx
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0065-1737
BD Animals and man; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Insect
   parasites; Hosts; Abiotic factors; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America
DE Bubo virginianus [Disturbance by man / Habitat fragmentation /
   prevalence; young] [Arachnid parasites / Glaucalges cf. attenuatus / ] [
   / Ornithonyssus sylviarum / ] [Anopluran parasites / Neohaematopinus
   sciurinus / ] [Dipteran parasites / Icosta americana / ] [Hemipteran
   parasites / Cimicidae / ] [Mallophagan parasites / Colpocephalum
   pectinatum / New record] [ /  / ] [ / Geomydoecus telli / ]
   [Siphonapteran parasites / Orchopeas / ] [Mexico / Baja California
   peninsula / ] [ /  / ]. 
   Cimicidae; Geomydoecus telli; Glaucalges cf. attenuatus; Icosta
   americana; Neohaematopinus sciurinus; Orchopeas; Ornithonyssus sylviarum
   [Avian hosts / Bubo virginianus / Prevalence] [Abiotic factors /
   Environmental factors / ] [Mexico / Baja California peninsula / ]. 
   Colpocephalum pectinatum [Avian hosts / Bubo virginianus / New record] [
   /  / Prevalence] [Abiotic factors / Environmental factors / ] [Mexico /
   Baja California peninsula / ] [ /  / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Birds; Chelicerates; Chordates; Insects;
   Invertebrates; True Bugs; True Flies; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari, Insecta, Anoplura, Diptera,
   Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha, Hippoboscidae, Hemiptera, Heteroptera,
   Cimicomorpha, Cimicoidea, Mallophaga, Siphonaptera, Chordata,
   Vertebrata, Aves, Strigiformes, Strigidae
OR Glaucalges cf. attenuatus (Acari): [Parasite]. 
   Ornithonyssus sylviarum (Acari): [Parasite]. 
   Neohaematopinus sciurinus (Anoplura): [Parasite]. 
   Icosta americana (Hippoboscidae): [Parasite]. 
   Cimicidae (Cimicoidea): [Parasite]. 
   Colpocephalum pectinatum (Mallophaga): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Geomydoecus telli (Mallophaga): [Parasite]. 
   Orchopeas (Siphonaptera): [Parasite]. 
   Bubo virginianus (Strigidae): [Host; New record].

DT Article
TI MICROCENTRUM TECACTLI, A NEW SPECIES OF PHANEROPTERIDAE (ORTHOPTERA:
   TETTIGONIOIDEA) FROM NORTHEASTERN MEXICO.
FT Microcentrum TECACTLI, nueva especie de PHANEROPTERIDAE (orthoptera:
   TETTIGONIOIDEA) del noreste de MEXICO.
AU Fernandez-Azuara, Geovany J.
   Rocha-Sanchez, Aurora Y.
   Barrientos-Lozano, Ludivina (biol.geofa@hotmail.com) 
   Correa-Sandoval, Alfonso
   Almaguer-Sierra, Pedro
SO Acta Zoologica Mexicana Nueva Serie
VL 34
PS 1-14
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Microcentrum tecactli n. sp., Barrientos-Lozano, Fernandez-Azuara &
   Rocha-Sanchez, 2018, is described from specimens collected in the
   Huasteca region in the State of Hidalgo Mexico. Microcentrum tecactli
   exhibits affinities with Microcentrum rhombifolium (Saussure, 1859).
   However, it differs in morphological and acoustic characters. In males
   the length of the stridulatory file is 4.2 mm with ca. 62 teeth vs. 4 mm
   ca. 55 teeth in M rhombifolium; the subgenital plate is distally more
   produced, the styles are shorter and diverging; the cerci are distally
   narrower, and the internal genitalia is different. Lone males produce
   two types of acoustic signals: i) a calling song that consists of a
   regular buzz made up of a single syllable (one Pulse Train Group),
   average duration 155[plus or minus]38 ms (78-212 ms) (3 males; n=29
   samples one min each), with inter-syllable interval (Major Interval=MaI)
   of 1483[plus or minus]364 ms (115-2394 ms). Frequency spectrum is
   between 4 to >30 kHz, peak frequency (fi) is at 6-16 kHz. Syllables
   repetition rate is 48[plus or minus]4.36/min (43-55; n=10 samples one
   min each). ii) Sequence of ticks made up of two paired-phrases with an
   average duration of 7.53[plus or minus]0.16 s (3 males; n=5
   paired-sequences of ticks); phrases 1 and 2 average duration is similar
   in each sequence, 2.3[plus or minus]0 s. The number of pulses per phrase
   is also the same in both phrases: 29 [plus or minus]0 each. Major
   interval duration between sequences of ticks of two paired-phrases is
   5.37[plus or minus]2.75 s. Minor interval duration between phrases 1 and
   2 is 1.42[plus or minus]0.12 s (1.27-1.51). Frequency range is between 4
   to >30 kHz, after 30 kHz the amount of energy is minimal. Dominant
   frequency spectrum ranges from 4 to 22 kHz and peak frequency (fi) is at
   6-16 kHz. Repetition rate of tick-paired sequences is 0.1/s (6/min); in
   four paired-sequences of ticks the repetition rate of pulses/ticks in
   phrases 1 and 2 was the same, 12.6/s each one.
C1 Barrientos-Lozano, Ludivina; Tecnol Ncl Mexico, Inst Tecnol Ciudad
   Victoria, Blvd Emilio Portes Gil 1301, Ciudad Victoria, Tamaulipas,
   87010, Mexico, Mexico.
EM biol.geofa@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0065-1737
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America
DE Microcentrum tecactli [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Microcentrum tecactli - Barrientos-Lozano, Fernandez-Azuara & Rocha 2018
   (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 4].

DT Article
TI HELMINTH FAUNA FROM THE DIGESTIVE AND RESPIRATORY SYSTEMS OF WATERFOWL
   (SUBFAMILY: ANATINAE) AT WETLAND OF ATLANGATEPEC, TLAXCALA MEXICO.
FT Helmintofauna del aparato digestivo y respiratorio de aves acuaticas
   (anatidae: ANATINAE) del humedal de ATLANGATEPEC, Tlaxcala, MEXICO.
AU Padilla-Aguilar, Patricia (mvz_patypadilla@yahoo.com) 
   Osorio-Sarabia, David
   Munoz-Garcia, Claudia I.
   Rendon-Franco, Emilio
   Romero-Callejas, Evangelina
SO Acta Zoologica Mexicana Nueva Serie
VL 34
PS 1-5
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The purpose of this investigation was to carry out the first inventory
   of helminths collected from waterfowl (n=52) of the family Anatidae.
   This work took place in wetland Atlangatepec, Tlaxcala. Hehninths were
   collected from the digestive tract and the respiratory system of
   waterfowl donated by hunters. Collected parasites were processed using
   conventional fixation and staining techniques for the identification of
   helminth. Twenty-one taxa of helminth swere identified as follow: seven
   trematodes (Cotylurus cornutus, Australa-patemon burti, Zygocotyle
   lunata, Notocotylus seineti, Typhlocoelum sisowi, Echinostoma sp. and
   Echinoparyphium recurvatum), four cestodes (Hymenolepis sp, Cloacotaenia
   megalops, Choanotaenia infundibulum and Fimbriaria fasciolaris), eight
   nematodes (Amidostontum sp., Streptocara sp., Epomidiostomum uncinatum,
   Syphaciella sp., Capillaria sp., Tetrameres fissispina, Tetrameres sp.
   and Echinuria uncinata) and two Acanthocephala (Pseudocorynosoma
   constritum and Polimorphus sp.). It is relevant to highlight that this
   is the first report of Syphaciella sp. in waterfowl in Mexico.
C1 Padilla-Aguilar, Patricia; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Fac Med Vet &

PT J
AN ZOOR15504023536
DT Article
TI On the three species of Cantharidae described by Grimmer.
AU Fanti, Fabrizio (fantifab@alice.it) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 135-137
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB With this work I discuss on the three species described by Grimmer in
   1841, which were then almost forgotten over the decades. The
   nomenclatural acts proposed here, are: Telephorus nigripes Grimmer, 1841
   = Cantharis quadripunctata (O. F. Miiller, 1776) n. syn. and Malthinus
   gracilis Grimmer, 1841 nomen dubium. Also Malthinus obscurus Grimmer,
   1841 is confirmed to be nomen dubium as already proposed by Burakowski
   et al. (1985).
C1 Fanti, Fabrizio; Via Tamburino 69, Piazze, Siena, I-53040, Italy, Italy.
EM fantifab@alice.it
SC Zoology
SN 1407-8619
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Available name
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cantharoidea,
   Cantharidae
OR Cantharis quadripunctata - (Mueller 1776) (Cantharidae): [Syn nov,
   Telephorus nigripes Grimmer 1841, p. 136]. 
   Malthinus gracilis - Grimmer 1841 (Cantharidae): [Nomen dubium, P. 136].
   
   Malthinus obscurus - Grimmer 1841 (Cantharidae): [Nomen dubium, P. 136].
   
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15504023536
DA 2020-09-17

TI Four New Species of Metapocyrtus Heller, 1912, from Mindoro Island,
   Philippines (Coleoptera, Curculionidae, Entiminae, Pachyrhynchini).

SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 139-158
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of the genus Metapocyrtus Heller (Entiminae:
   Pachyrhynchini) are described from Mindoro Island, The Philippines: M.
   bacoensis sp. nov., M. coeruleolineatus sp. nov., M. rubricollis sp.
   nov., and H. yoshitakei sp. nov. The diagnosis of each species is
   provided. Habitus photographs and illustrations of male and female
   genitalia of the new species are also given.

DT Article
TI First finding of the genus Paramaechidius Frey, 1969 from the Indonesian
   province Maluku (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Melolonthinae).
AU Prokofiev, Artem M. (prokartster@gmail.com) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 159-163
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Paramaechidius agnellus spec. nov. is described from Seram Island
   (Maluku province, Indonesia). It is very similar to P. pauxillus
   (Heller, 1910) and P. speciosus Frey, 1969 in appearance, but can be
   easily distinguished from these species by the structure of the
   aedeagus. The genus Paramaechidius is recorded outside of New Guinea and
   the nearby islands for the first time.
C1 Prokofiev, Artem M.; Russian Acad Sci, AN Severtsov Inst Ecol & Evolut,
   Leninsky Prospect 33, Moscow, 119071, Russia, Russia.
EM prokartster@gmail.com

   region; Eurasia; Asia

   Paramaechidius [Indonesia / Maluku / New record]. 
   Paramaechidius agnellus [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Scarabaeidae

   162]. 
   Paramaechidius (Scarabaeidae): [New record]. 
   Paramaechidius agnellus (Scarabaeidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 160].

DT Article
TI Ctenostoma (Neoprocephalus) antonkozlovi sp. n. from Bolivia
   (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Cicindelinae).
AU Sciaky, Riccardo (riccardo.sciaky@virgilio.it) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 171-174
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ctenostoma (Neoprocephalus) antonkozlovi sp. n. from Bolivia is
   described and compared with the most related species. This new species
   belongs to the cylindratum-group and in particular seems near C.
   germaini in general shape of the body, elytral punctation and shape of
   the head. A list of the species of Ctenostoma described after Naviaux'
   revision (1998) and of the species of Ctenostoma presently known from
   Bolivia are also provided.
C1 Sciaky, Riccardo; Via Fiamma 13, Milan, I-20129, Italy, Italy.

   [Bolivia /  / ].

DT Article
TI New findings of weevils (Coleoptera, Curculionioidea) in Baltic amber.
AU Legalov, Andrei A. (fossilweevils@gmail.com) 
   Bukejs, Andris
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 179-183
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New findings of five weevil species in Baltic amber are given.
   Morphological characters of sexual dimorphism of Palaeometrioxena
   zherikhini Legalov, 2012 and Succinometrioxena poinari Legalov, 2012 are
   shown for the first time. Caulophilus sucinopunctatus (Kunka, 1992),
   comb. n., placem. n. is transferred from the genus Phloeophagus
   Schoenherr, 1838 of the tribe Rhyncolini to the genus Caulophilus
   Wollaston, 1854 of the tribe Dryotribini. Key to species of Caulophilus
   known from Eocene amber is given.
C1 Legalov, Andrei A.; Russian Acad Sci, Siberian Branch, Frunze St 11,
   Novosibirsk, 630091, Russia, Russia.

TI Metapocyrtus (Artapocyrtus) willietorresi sp. n. (Coleoptera:
   Curculionidae) from Southern Mindanao (Philippines), with notes on its
   ecology and mimicry complex.
AU Cabras, Analyn A. (ann.cabras24@umindanao.edu.ph) 
   Medina, Milton Norman D.
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 185-192
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Metapocyrtus (Artapocyrtus) willietorresi sp.n. is described and
   illustrated. Ecological and biological data are given, including mimicry
   with species of Pachyrhynchus Germar, 1824 and Doliops Waterhouse, 1841
   (Cerambycidae). Notes on the threats of this new species are furnished
   and a proposal to raise its conservation status as Threatened are
   presented.

DT Article
TI Descriptions of two new Australian genera of Anthicidae (Insecta:
   Coleoptera).
AU Telnov, Dmitry (anthicus@gmail.com) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 199-218
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new Australian Anthicidae genera, Australosteropes gen. nov.
   (Steropinae) and Sahulanthicus gen. nov. (Anthicinae: Anthicini) are
   described, diagnosed, and illustrated. Some critical morphological
   characters of these new groups and the subfamilies to which they belong
   are discussed. New combinations are made for the following 18 taxa:
   Australosteropes davidsonae (Armstrong, 1948) comb. nov. (from Macratria
   Newman, 1838), Sahulanthicus abundans (Lea, 1922) comb. nov., S.
   apicalis (King, 1869) comb. nov., S. baudinensis (Champion, 1895) comb.
   nov., S. brevicollis (King, 1869) comb. nov., S. cavifrons (Champion,
   1895) comb. nov., S. crassipes (LaFerte-Senectere, 1849) comb. nov., S.
   crassus (King, 1869) comb. nov., S. discoideus (Champion, 1895) comb.
   nov., S. immaculatus (King, 1869) comb. nov., S. inglorius (Lea, 1896)
   comb. nov., S. laticollis (MacLeay, 1872) comb. nov., S. luridus (King,
   1869) comb. nov., S. monostigma (Champion, 1895) comb. nov., S.
   obliquefasciatus (King, 1869) comb. nov., S. permutatus (Pic, 1897)
   comb. nov., S. scutellatus (Lea, 1896) comb. nov. (all from Microhoria
   Chevrolat, 1877), and S. dilatipennis (Pic, 1900) comb. nov. (from
   Anthicus Paykull, 1798). Lectotype is designated for Sahulanthicus
   dilatipennis (Pic, 1900).
C1 Telnov, Dmitry; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Life Sci, London, SW7 5BD, United
   Kingdom, United Kingdom.

DT Article
TI Nomenclatural notes on Anthicidae and Pyrochroidae (Coleoptera). 6.
AU Telnov, Dmitry (anthicus@gmail.com) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 219-278
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five new combinations, three new synonyms and two new statuses for the
   Anthicidae are proposed. New distributional data or corrections are
   provided on 65 taxa of Pyrochroidae and Anthicidae. Eighteen new species
   and subspecies are described: Anthelephila panayensis sp. nov., Anthicus
   (s. str.) chitwanus sp. nov., A. (s. str.) lepcha sp. nov., A. (s. str.)
   vicinor sp. nov., Aulacoderus muehlei sp. nov., Clavicomus garze sp.
   nov., C. kham sp. nov., Cyclodinus phragmiteticola sp. nov., Macratria
   dotyali sp. nov., M. kopetzi sp. nov., M. leprieuri gasconica ssp. nov.,
   Macratriomima casuarius sp. nov., M. chandleri sp. nov., Notoxus reuteri
   sp. nov., Rimaderus bonadonai sp. nov., R. sahyadri sp. nov., Stenidius
   obliquesetosus sp. nov., and Tomoderus schmidti sp. nov. Additional
   description is given for Anthelephila kresli Kejval, 2007 and
   Yunnanomonticola Telnov, 2002.
C1 Telnov, Dmitry; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Life Sci, London, SW7 5BD, United
   Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM anthicus@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1407-8619

TI Two new species of the genus Pachyrhynchus (Coleoptera: Curculionidae:
   Pachyrhynchini) from Mindanao, Philippines.
AU Rukmane, Anita (anitakraslava@inbox.lv) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 283-290
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species belonging to genus Pachyrhynchus are described from
   Mindanao Island: P. sergejevae sp. n. Rukmane, 2018; P torresi sp. n.
   Rukmane, 2018. Pictures and description of habbitus are added, together
   with distribution maps for both of species. Male genitalia and female
   terminalia are illustrated.

TI Two new species of the genus Callimetopus Blanchard, 1911 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae) from Palawan and Marinduque islands (Philippines).
AU Barsevskis, Arvids (arvids.barsevskis@du.lv) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 291-296
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of long-horned beetles of the genus Callimetopus
   Blanchard, 1853 from the Philippines are described and illustrated: C.
   bumbierisi sp. n. (Palawan) and C. marinduquensis sp. n. (Marinduque).
   The genus Callimetopus is now represented by 49 species.

TI New species and subspecies of Doliops Waterhouse, 1841 and Lamprobityle
   Heller, 1923 (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae) from the Philippines.
AU Barsevskis, Arvids (arvids.barsevskis@du.lv) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 297-304
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New species and a new subspecies of the genus Doliops Waterhouse, 1841
   and a new species of the genus Lamprobityle Heller, 1923 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae) are described and illustrated: D. um sp. n., D. basilana
   zamboangana ssp. n. and L. medinai sp. n. The genus Doliops in the world
   fauna is now represented by 59 species, and the genus Lamprobityle by 13
   species.

TI A new species and a new synonymy in the genus Agnia Newman, 1842
   (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae).
AU Barsevskis, Arvids (arvids.barsevskis@du.lv) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 18
IS 2
PS 309-317
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Agnia rita sp. n. from Panay Island (Philippines) is described and
   illustrated, the lectotype of Agnia clara is designated and a new
   synonymy is proposed: A. clara Newman, 1842 = A. lucipor Breuning, 1982,
   syn. n. A catalogue of the genus Agnia Newman, 1842 is given. The genus
   Agnia is now represented by eight species.

   Str 13, Daugavpils, LV-5401, Latvia, Latvia.

PT J
AN ZOOR15504021925
DT Article
TI NEW HOST RECORD OF SOME GASTROINTESTINAL PARASITES OF IRRAWADDY SQUIRREL
   (CALLOSCIURUS PYGERYTHRUS) FROM CHITTAGONG, BANGLADESH.
AU Hussain, Md Afzal (afzalkamal84@gmail.com) 
   Acharjee, Rajib
   Ahmed, Benazir
SO Bangladesh Journal of Zoology
VL 46
IS 2
PS 87-103
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Gastrointestinal (GI) tract of 60 Irrawaddy squirrels (Callosciurus
   pygerythrus) were collected between September 2013 and August 2014 from
   four different spots of Chittagong University campus and its adjacent
   areas to study the ento-helminth fauna. Eight different parasite species
   were identified - one belonging to Cestoda and represented by
   Hymenolepis diminuta, and the remaining seven were to Nematoda viz.,
   Strongyloides callosciurus, Trichuris ovis, Monodontus sp.,
   Cyclodontostomum purvisi, Moguranema nipponicum, Ascarops talpa and
   Syphacia obvelata. The nematodes were found as dominant species most
   preferably inhabiting the small intestine. The present host is the new
   host record for all of these parasites and S. callosciurus, T. ovis,
   Monodontus sp., M. nipponicum and A. talpa are the new records for
   Bangladesh too. All these parasites have very wide host specificity,
   though most of them are restricted to various rodent hosts but H.
   diminuta and S. callosciurus were found to have more wider specificity,
   including other vertebrates too. All identified parasites might have
   been acquired from the environment where the host inhabits, since host
   specificity perspective no parasites were found to be specific to the
   present host. H. diminuta and Syphacia obvelata might have zoonotic role
   to other wild animals and human and vice versa.
C1 Hussain, Md Afzal; Univ Chittagong, Dept Zool, Chittagong, 4331,
   Bangladesh, Bangladesh.
EM afzalkamal84@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0304-9027
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Ascarops talpa; Cyclodontostomum purvisi; Hymenolepis diminuta;
   Moguranema nipponicum; Monodontus; Strongyloides callosciurus; Syphacia
   obvelata; Trichuris ovis [Mammalian hosts / Callosciurus pygerythrus /
   Host specificity; new record] [Bangladesh /  / ]. 
   Callosciurus pygerythrus [Cestode parasites / Hymenolepis diminuta /
   Host specificity; new record] [Nematode parasites / Ascarops talpa / ] [
   / Cyclodontostomum purvisi / ] [ / Moguranema nipponicum / ] [ /
   Monodontus / ] [ / Strongyloides callosciurus / ] [ / Syphacia obvelata
   / ] [ / Trichuris ovis / ] [Bangladesh /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Nematodes; Platyhelminths; Rodents;
   Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Sciuridae, Nematoda,
   Platyhelminthes, Cestoda
OR Callosciurus pygerythrus (Sciuridae): [Host; New record]. 
   Ascarops talpa (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Cyclodontostomum purvisi (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Moguranema nipponicum (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Monodontus (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Strongyloides callosciurus (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Syphacia obvelata (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Trichuris ovis (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Hymenolepis diminuta (Cestoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15504021925

DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15504019452
DT Article
TI A new species of Caecilia Linnaeus, 1758 (Amphibia: Gymnophiona:
   Caeciliidae) from French Guiana.
AU Maciel, Adriano Oliveira (aombiologo@yahoo.com.br) 
   Hoogmoed, Marinus Steven
SO Boletim do Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi Ciencias Naturais
VL 13
IS 1
PS 13-18
PD Jan 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a new species of the genus Caecilia from French Guiana. The
   new species differs from most species of the genus in the numbers of
   primary and secondary grooves. Color pattern, body shape, presence of
   subdermal scales, and number of teeth separate Caecilia museugoeldi sp.
   nov. from the other species of the genus. This new taxon is the first of
   the genus described in 33 years.
C1 Maciel, Adriano Oliveira; Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi, MCTIC, Av

DT Article
TI Aetiology and histopathology of a systemic phaeohyphomycosis in farmed
   lumpfish, Cyclopterus lumpus.
AU Johnson, K.E.
   Freeman, M.A. (mafreeman@rossvet.edu.kn) 
   Laxdal, B.
   Kristmundsson, A.
SO Bulletin of the European Association of Fish Pathologists
VL 38
IS 5
PS 187-194
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Lumpfish being reared as biological control agents for sea lice removal
   from farmed Atlantic salmon developed mycotic lesions in their skeletal
   muscle, heart, and kidneys. After necropsy and histopathology, the fish
   were diagnosed with phaeohyphomycosis, thought to be caused by Exophiala
   sp. Samples of lesions were sent for molecular analysis to confirm the
   diagnosis. PCR and DNA sequencing confirmed the presence of two fungal
   species of black yeasts (Chaetothyriales) Exophiala psychrophilia and
   Cyphellophora sp. Exophiala spp. are known pathogens of farmed salmon,
   wild fishes, and other animals including humans. Cyphellophora spp. are
   normally found colonising plants and land animals, but have not been
   reported from fish. Most phaeohyphomycoses in captive fish are thought
   to be secondary to a compromised immune system arising from infections
   with primary pathogens, and/or husbandry problems. The identification of
   these fungal infections in cultured lumpfish and the increasing reports
   of microsporidiosis in captive lumpfish, are a reminder that further
   research is needed to understand the physiology and husbandry needs of
   this relatively new fish to aquaculture, especially with respect to
   opportunistic pathogens. In addition, the zoonotic potential of these
   pathogens in the aquaculture environment should be evaluated.
C1 Freeman, M.A.; Ross Univ, Sch Vet Med, Basseterre, Saint Kitts and
   Nevis, Saint Kitts and Nevis.
EM mafreeman@rossvet.edu.kn
RI Freeman, Mark A/B-7777-2010; Johnson, Kelsey/AAC-1824-2019
OI Johnson, Kelsey/0000-0003-2043-3666

SN 0108-0288
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Diseases and disorders; Microbial
   diseases; Ecology; Population dynamics

   pathology; farmed] [ / Exophiala psychrophilia / Case report; aetiology]
   [Mortality /  / ] [ /  / ].

   Scorpaeniformes, Cyclopteridae
OR Cyclopterus lumpus (Cyclopteridae).

DT Article
TI Systemic mycoses in lumpfish (Cyclopterus lumpus L.) in Ireland:
   aetiology and clinical presentation.
AU Scholz, F. (felixlscholz@hotmail.com) 
   Ruane, N.M.
   Marcos-Lopez, M.
   Mitchell, S.
   Bolton-Warberg, M.
   O'Connor, I.
   Mirimin, L.
   MacCarthy, E.
   Rodger, H.D.
SO Bulletin of the European Association of Fish Pathologists
VL 38
IS 5
PS 202-212
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Systemic infections with predominantly Exophiala species have emerged as
   regular and significant pathogens of lumpfish in Ireland and abroad.
   Exophiala is a genus of melanised fungi in the order Chaetothyriales.
   They are regularly found as opportunistic pathogens of cold blooded
   vertebrates and several species have caused high mortalities in
   aquaculture. In 2016 and 2017, E. angulospora, E. psychrophila, E.
   salmonis and a Cyphellophora sp. were identified as the causes of
   phaeohyphomycosis in lumpfish in Ireland, as confirmed through clinical
   presentation, histopathology, wet mounts, fungal culture, sequencing of
   the ITS region and phylogenetic analysis. Systemic pathology was severe,
   characterised by segmented, pigmented hyphae in the host tissues
   associated with severe necrosis and inflammation. Significant chronic
   mortality in lumpfish broodstock in Ireland was attributed to E.
   angulospora and E. psychrophila. E. angulospora was also isolated from
   cases with multiple infectious aetiologies. E. salmonis and a
   Chyphellophora sp. were diagnosed in lumpfish at sea. This is the first
   record of E. salmonis in lumpfish.
C1 Scholz, F.; FishVet Grp Ireland, Unit Oranmore Business Pk 7b, Oranmore,
   Co Galway, Republic of Ireland, Republic of Ireland.
EM felixlscholz@hotmail.com
OI Rodger, Hamish/0000-0002-5336-8912

   diseases; Ecology; Population dynamics

   phylogenetic analysis] [ / Exophiala psychrophila / ] [ / Exophiala
   salmonis / New record; in captivity] [ /  / ] [Mortality /  / ].

DT Article
TI Pseudomonas anguilliseptica associated with mortalities in lumpfish
   (Cyclopterus lumpus L.) reared in Scotland.
AU Treasurer, J.W. (jim.treasurer@faifarms.com) 
   Birkbeck, T.H.
SO Bulletin of the European Association of Fish Pathologists
VL 38
IS 5
PS 222-224
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Lumpsucker, Cyclopterus lumpus, larvae were reared successfully in a
   Scottish marine hatchery but, following a period of exceptionally high
   hatchery water temperatures of over 16.5[degree]C, bacterial infections
   occurred. This was associated with Ps. anguilliseptica, a Photobacterium
   sp. and Aliivibrio logei. The infections were successfully controlled by
   oxytetracycline treatment.

DT Article
TI STRINGOCEPHALID BRACHIOPODS IN THE UPPER GIVETIAN (LATE MIDDLE DEVONIAN)
   OF SOUTHEASTERN ALASKA (CORONADOS ISLANDS) AND THEIR
   PALEOBIOGEOGRAPHICAL SIGNIFICANCE.
AU Baranov, Valeryi V. (vbaranov@diamond.ysn.ru) 
   Blodgett, Robert B.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 79
PS 17-30
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The following stringocephalid brachiopods are described from a new upper
   Givetian (late Middle Devonian) collection in strata of the Coronados
   Volcanics in southeastern Alaska (Coronados Islands, near the town on
   Craig on western Prince of Wales Island): Stringocephalus axius
   Crickmay, 1954 (subfamily Stringocephalinae), Alekseevathyris
   coronadosensis gen. and n. sp. (subfamily Omoloninae), Newberria
   alaskensis n. sp., Churkinella craigensis n. gen. and n. sp. and
   Coronadothyris mica n. gen. and n. sp. (subfamily Rensselandinae).
   Paleobiogeographical connections between the seas of southeastern
   Alaska, western Canada (British Columbia), Northeast Asia and Nevada are
   clearly established in the late Givetian (late Middle Devonian).

DT Article
TI TOURNAISIAN (EARLY CARBONIFEROUS) CONODONTS OF THE NEW SIBERIAN ISLANDS
   (RUSSIAN ARCTIC).
AU Baranov, Valeryi V. (baranowvalera@yandex.ru) 
   Blodgett, Robert B.
   Ershova, Victoria B.
   Prokopiev, Andrei V.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 79
PS 31-36
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A conodont fauna from the Tournaisian beds (upper part of the Chekurskay
   Suite) of the New Siberian Islands (Russian Arctic) is described for the
   first time. The fauna is represented by eleven species: Bispathodus
   aculeatus aculeatus, Clydagnathus unicornis, Fungulodus sp., Hindeodella
   sp., Ligonodina sp., Lonchodina sp., ?Lochriea sp., Mitrellataxis cf.
   coronella, Neoprioniodus scitulus, Ozarkodina sp., and Spathognathodus
   sp. It is characteristic for the Kharaulakh-Novosibirsk province, which
   is a part of the Arctic Realm (Baranov, Grinenko, Blodgett, 2018). An
   analysis of the geographical distribution of conodonts of the
   Tournaisian conodonts of the New Siberian Islands shows that in addition
   to the cosmopolitan Bispathodus aculeatus aculeatus and Clydagnathus
   unicornis are cosmopolitan in distribution, while the species
   Mitrellataxis cf. coronella and Neoprioniodus scitulus are known from
   Early Carboniferous deposits of North America and northwestern India.
   The above fact indicates the existence of biogeographical relationships
   between these areas.
C1 Baranov, Valeryi V.; Russian Acad Sci, Siberian Div, Lenin Prospect 39,
   Yakutsk, 677980, Russia, Russia.

   Cyrtiopsinae), and Athyris sp. (family Athyrididae).

DT Article
TI THE PRESENCE OF THE GENUS ZDIMIRELLA CHERKESOVA (DEVONIAN BRACHIOPODA)
   IN NORTH AMERICA (ARCTIC CANADA).
AU Blodgett, Robert B. (robertbblodgett@gmail.com) 
   Pedder, Alan E.H.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 79
PS 75-81
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The extremely rare gypidulid brachiopod named Pentamerus borealis by
   Meek (1868) is redescribed and refigured as a species of the genus
   Zdimirella Cherkesova, 1973. This is the first recognition of the
   previously monotypic Zdimirella outside of its type occurrence at the
   "base of the Givetian" on the South Island of Novaya Zemlya, Russian
   Federation. Partly based upon new brachiopod and coral data provided in
   an appendix, the distribution of Z. borealis is likely confined to the
   latest Eifelian ensensis Zone in the uppermost Hume Formation of
   northern Anderson Plain, and Z. kuzmini, the other species of the genus
   from the Chernogub horizon of Novaya Zemlya, is also likely to be of
   late Eifelian age. These only known occurrences of the genus suggest a
   faunal tie between the Middle Devonian of at least the northeastern
   extremity of northwestern Canada and Novaya Zemlya. In Middle Devonian
   time, present-day southern Novaya Zemlya and Anderson Plain belonged to
   the same Old World Realm as envisioned by Johnson and Boucot (1973),
   Boucot (1975) and Boucot and Blodgett (2001). The identification of the
   brachiopod Helaspis in the Hume Formation of Anderson Plain is
   additional evidence of the Devonian faunal connection between
   northwestern Canada and present-day US midcontinent, as advocated by
   Koch and Day (1996).
C1 Blodgett, Robert B.; 2821 Kingfisher Dr, Anchorage, AK, 99502, USA, USA.
EM robertbblodgett@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1524-4156

DT Article
TI A NEW CERATOPSID DINOSAUR (CENTROSAURINAE: NASUTOCERATOPSINI) FROM THE
   FORT CRITTENDEN FORMATION, UPPER CRETACEOUS (CAMPANIAN) OF ARIZONA.
AU Dalman, Sebastian G. (sebastiandalman@yahoo.com) 
   Hodnett, John-Paul M.
   Lichtig, Asher J.
   Lucas, Spencer G.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 79
PS 141-164
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new ceratopsid dinosaur, Crittendenceratops krzyzanowskii, is
   described from the Fort Crittenden Formation (Upper Cretaceous) of
   southeastern Arizona, and is based on two individuals consisting of
   partial cranial material recovered from the same stratigraphic unit. A
   phylogenetic analysis of ceratopsids recovers Crittendenceratops as a
   member of Nasutoceratopsini, a subclade of Centrosaurinae defined as the
   stem-based Glade of centrosaurine ceratopsids more closely related to
   Avaceratops lammersi and Nasutoceratops titusi than to Centrosaurus
   apertus. Reconstruction of the parietosquamosal frill based on two
   specimens indicates that C. krzyzanowskii is a unique, nasutoceratopsin
   taxon. The parietosquamosal frill of C. krzyzanowskii had a broad medial
   ramus and at least five epiparietal loci situated around the margin of
   the frill, a typical characteristic of Centrosaurinae. The epiparietals
   are pronounced triangles that are dorsally concave and ventrally convex.
   Additionally, two large, triangular hook-like flanges, nearly the size
   of the epiparietal loci, are situated along the dorsomedial margin of
   the parietal ramus. The left squamosal has a pronounced dorsal ridge
   with a single dorsal squamosal process and large episquamosal
   undulations, a typical characteristic of Centrosaurinae. The presence of
   C. krzyzanowskii in Arizona indicates that the nasutoceratopsins
   persisted into the late Campanian. The temporal and paleobiogeographic
   distribution of Nasutoceratopsini further weakens the hypothesis of
   distinct northern and southern Laramidian provinces.
C1 Dalman, Sebastian G.; New Mexico Museum Nat Hist, 1801 Mt Rd NW,
   Albuquerque, NM, 87104, USA, USA.
EM sebastiandalman@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1524-4156

   region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   /  / ].

DT Article
TI A NONMARINE LATE PENNSYLVANIAN VERTEBRATE ASSEMBLAGE IN A MARINE
   BROMALITE FROM THE MANZANITA MOUNTAINS, BERNALILLO COUNTY, NEW MEXICO.
AU Hodnett, John-Paul M. (jp.hodnett@pgparks.com) 
   Lucas, Spencer G.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 79
PS 251-260
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A coprolite rich in freshwater fish teeth, scales, dermal cranial bones,
   and a large amphibian maxilla is preserved in a single isolated marine
   limestone rock. This specimen was collected from a upper marine
   limestone interval of the upper Tinajas Member of the Atrasado Formation
   and is stratigraphically higher than the Tinajas and Kinney Brick Quarry
   localities that are known to be rich in vertebrate fossils. Fish
   identified from this coprolite include the xenacanth shark Orthacanthus
   cf. O. donneljohnsi, and three actinopterygians well known from Kinney
   Brick Quarry: Schizolepis sp., "palaeonisciform type 1" and either
   "palaeonisciform type 5" or "palaeonisciform type 6." The amphibian
   maxilla is from an indeterminate eogyrinid anthracosaur, the first of
   its kind identified from the Atrasado Formation. We propose that the
   coprolite was produced by a large shark, such as Ghlananius
   occidentalis, which was capable of feeding upstream in brackish or fresh
   waters, and later returned to the shallow marine carbonate shelf.
C1 Hodnett, John-Paul M.; Maryland Natl Capital Pk & Planning Commiss, Nat
   & Hist Resources Div, 8204 McClure Rd, Upper Marlboro, MD, 20772, USA,
   USA.
EM jp.hodnett@pgparks.com

DT Article
TI MOSASAUR COPROLITES FROM THE BEARPAW FORMATION (UPPER CRETACEOUS) OF
   SASKATCHEWAN, CANADA.
AU Hunt, Adrian P. (adrianhu@flyingheritage.org) 
   Lucas, Spencer G.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 79
PS 271-275
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Coprolites of marine reptiles were first described in the early
   nineteenth century. During the 1980s, coprolites were found in the
   Bearpaw Formation (Upper Cretaceous; upper Campanian) in southern
   Saskatchewan. Beechybromus wellschi igen. et isp. nov. is a coprolite
   that is elongate and sub cylindrical with rounded cross section and is
   composed of up to 12 discoidal segments; the posterior termination is
   rounded, and the anterior consists of a triangular apex. It most
   probably pertains to a mosasaur. A partial specimen from Kansas may
   pertain to this ichnogenus. Segmented coprolites are typical of
   mosasaurs.
C1 Hunt, Adrian P.; Flying Heritage & Combat Armor Museum, 3407 109thSt SW,
   Everett, WA, 98204, USA, USA.
EM adrianhu@flyingheritage.org
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 1524-4156
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Fossil traces; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; Canada; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic

   Mosasauroidea (Reptilia), Cretaceous / ] [Cretaceous /  / New genus
   described from fossil excreta; Possibly attributable to Mosasauroidea
   (Reptilia)]. 
   Beechybromus wellschi [Fossil excreta / New species possibly
   attributable to Mosasauroidea (Reptilia), Cretaceous, Saskatchewan / ]
   [Saskatchewan /  / new species; Described from fossil excreta; possibly
   attributable to Mosasauroidea (Reptilia)] [Cretaceous /  / ].

PT J

DT Article
TI THE RECORD OF SLOTH COPROLITES IN NORTH AND SOUTH AMERICA: IMPLICATIONS
   FOR TERMINAL PLEISTOCENE EXTINCTIONS.
AU Hunt, Adrian P. (adrianhu@flyingheritage.org) 
   Lucas, Spencer G.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 79
PS 277-298
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The first sloth coprolites were collected at the end of the Nineteenth
   Century at Cueva de Milodon in Chile. There are 23 localities in North
   and South America and the West Indies that yield sloth coprolites. All
   occurrences of sloth coprolites in the United States represent
   Nothrotheriops shastensis and are from late Rancholabrean caves. Gypsum
   Cave in Nevada and Rampart Cave in Arizona contain large latrinites of
   sloth coprolites. Other North American localities are Muav Caves
   (Arizona), Aden Crater and Shelter Cave (New Mexico), Upper Sloth Cave,
   Lower Sloth Cave, Dust Cave, Williams Cave (Texas) and Bechan Cave and
   Cowboy Cave (Utah). South American localities have coprolites of at
   least four genera and are Pikimachay Cave (Peru), Peas de las Trampas
   1.1, Cueva Cacao 1A, Gruta del Indio, Cuchillo Curd and Cerro Casa de
   Piedra 7 (Argentina), Cueva del Milodon (Chile), Lapa Vermelha IV and
   Gruta de Brejoes (Brazil). Bones of sloths are widespread in the Greater
   and Lesser Antilles but coprolites only occur at three localities in
   Cuba at Ciego Montero, Quemado de Guines and Solapa del Megalocnus. All
   the North American coprolites pertain to Castrocopros martini igen. et
   isp. nov. and those from Cueva del Milodon to Castrocopros hauthali
   igen. et isp. nov. In 9 caves, mainly in North America, the presence of
   sloths is based solely on coprolites (sometimes associated with hair) as
   osteological specimens are absent: (1) Muav Caves; (2) Bechan Cave; (3)
   Cowboy Cave; (4) Upper Sloth Cave; (5) Lower Sloth Cave; (6) Dust Cave;
   (7) Williams Cave; (8) Cuchillo Curd; and (9) Cerro Casa de Piedra 7.
   Proposed hypotheses as to why sloth may have inhabited caves include;
   (1) reproduction maternal den site; (2) obtaining nutrients; (3)
   shelter; and (4) low metabolism. There is limited evidence for predation
   on giant ground sloths, either by Pleistocene predators or humans; (1)
   North America - femur of Megalonyx jeffersonii with possible butchering
   marks; tracks of sloths associated with ?human tracks; and (2) South
   America- a Lestodon clavicle with putative marks from butchering,
   associated skeletons of Glossotherium and lithics. The record of sloth
   dung supports other evidence that there is less indication of survival
   of the megafauna into the Holocene in North America than South America.
   There is an acme of sloth coprolite preservation in the latest
   Pleistocene (also the only latrinites of Mammuthus and Bison) which
   suggests greater usage of caves by large herbivores at this time. The
   pattern of preservation of sloth coprolites suggests that climate rather
   than overkill was most significant in the extinction of ground sloths.
C1 Hunt, Adrian P.; Flying Heritage & Combat Armor Museum, 3407 109thSt SW,
   Everett, WA, 98204, USA, USA.
EM adrianhu@flyingheritage.org
SC Paleontology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1524-4156
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Ecology; Fossil traces;
   Land zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North America; USA;
   South America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary

DT Article
TI A new species of Aulocera Butler, 1867 (Lepidoptera; Nymphalidae,
   Satyrinae) from north-eastern Himalayas.
AU Katayama, Toshihiko
SO Butterflies
VL 79
PS 4-10
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Aulocera Butler, 1867 is described from
   Arnachal Pradesh state in India and Kachin state in Myanmar. The species
   appears closely related to Aulocera loha, but can be distinguished by
   large-size, developed brachia and saccus of male genitalia, and broad
   discal white bands on both wings.

DT Article
TI Confirmation of the true identity of Papilio alcibiades Fabricius, 1787
   (Lepidoptera: Papilionidae).
AU Cotton, Adam M. (adamcot@cscoms.com) 
SO Butterflies
VL 79
PS 11-17
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The syntypes of Papilio alcibiades Fabricius, 1787 have been treated as
   originating in South India or Java, but are shown here to represent the
   population of Graphium antiphates Cramer, 1775 from the Malay Peninsula
   on the basis of phenotype and historical records of the travels of the
   collector. Relevant nomenclatorial changes are applied as a result of
   the findings, and an updated synonymic listing of the species is
   presented.
C1 Cotton, Adam M.; 86-2 Moo 5, Chiang Mai, Thailand, Thailand.
EM adamcot@cscoms.com
SC Zoology
SN 2189-3896
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Papilionidae
OR Graphium antiphates alcibiades - (Fabricius 1787) (Papilionidae): [Syn
   nov, Graphium antiphates itamputi (Butler 1885), p. 15].

DT Article
TI Report on some monstrilloids (Crustacea: Copepoda) from Turkey with
   description of two new species.
AU Suarez-Morales, Eduardo (esuarez@ecosur.mx) 
   Ustun, Funda
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 59
IS 6
PS 547-562
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Monstrilloid copepods collected during zooplankton surveys carried out
   in Turkish coastal waters of the southern Black Sea were examined. A
   total of 3 species were found, of which two are undescribed, one of
   Cymbasoma Thompson, 1888 and one of Monstrillopsis Sars, 1921. The new
   species are described, illustrated and compared herein with their
   congeners. The new Cymbasoma belongs to a small group of species with
   the fifth leg exopodal lobe bearing two long outer setae and a minute
   inner seta; it can be distinguished by the shape of the genital somite
   and the asymmetry of the fifth leg endopodal lobes. The new
   Monstrillopsis is unique in having an unfused distal spine on the distal
   segment of the male antennule and paired processes at the base of the
   genital lappets. We also recorded the presumably widespread Monstrilla
   grandis Giesbrecht, 1893. The male specimen examined has some remarkable
   characters, particularly in the swimming legs 1-4, including a reduced,
   modified inner seta on the second segment of both first leg endopodal
   rami. Also, the inner seta of the first endopodal segment of legs 1-3 is
   absent and is present only on leg 4. Males of this species are less
   common than females; its intraspecific morphological variability
   compared with previous illustrated reports. The addition of the new
   species here described brings the number of nominal species of
   Monstrilloida in the Mediterranean-Black Sea region to 28.
C1 Suarez-Morales, Eduardo; El Colegio Frontera Sur ECOSUR, Unidad
   Chetumal, Chetumal, Quintana Roo, 77014, Mexico, Mexico.
EM esuarez@ecosur.mx
RI Ustun, Funda/P-8143-2019
SC Zoology
SN 0007-9723
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Cymbasoma turcorum; Monstrillopsis pontoeuxinensis [Black Sea / Turkey /
   New species]. 
   Monstrilloida [Black Sea / Turkey, Sinop Peninsula / Systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Monstrilloida
OR Monstrilloida (Copepoda). 
   Cymbasoma turcorum (Monstrilloida): [Sp nov, Turkey (marine), P. 548]. 
   Monstrilla grandis - Giesbrecht 1891 (Monstrilloida): [Redescription,
   Male, p. 559]. 
   Monstrillopsis pontoeuxinensis (Monstrilloida): [Sp nov, Turkey
   (marine), P. 553].

DT Article
TI A new species of genus Owenia Delle-Chiaje, 1844 (Annelida: Oweniidae)
   from the coast of Venezuela.
AU Felipe Diaz-Diaz, Oscar
   Parapar, Julio (jparapar@udc.es) 
   Moreira, Juan
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 59
IS 6
PS 589-597
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The study of several specimens belonging to the genus Owenia Delle
   Chiaje, 1844 (Annelida; Oweniidae), collected from the north-western
   coast of the Gulf of Venezuela, Caribbean Sea, revealed the presence of
   a new species, Owenia vieitezi sp. nov. The new taxon differs from other
   closely related species in presenting a branchial crown provided with
   three pairs of tentacles, and brown coloration in the ventral region of
   the peristomium and dorsal and lateral tentacles of the branchial crown.

   15008, Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI A new species of Shoemakerella Pirlot, 1936 (Amphipoda: Amphilochidea:
   Lysianassidae) from Gulf of California, NE Pacific Ocean, with an
   identification key for the known species of the genus.
AU Ortiz, Manuel
   Capetillo, Norberto
   Winfield, Ignacio (ignacioc@unam.mx) 
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 59
IS 6
PS 599-605
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Shoemakerella from the Gulf of California, Mexico, is
   herein described. It was caught from a puerulus spiny lobster collector,
   anchored at Punta Coyote, Gulf of California. The new species differs
   from all others by having a fissure on distal part of basis on pereopods
   3-7. An identification key for all known species in the genus is also
   provided. The new species is the first record of the genus from the
   Western Coast of Mexico.
C1 Winfield, Ignacio; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Fac Estudios Super
   Iztacala, Mexico City, DF, Mexico, Mexico.

DT Article
TI Dorylaimopsis heteroapophysis sp. nov. (Comesomatidae: Nematoda) from
   the Jiaozhou Bay of China.
AU Huang, Mian
   Sun, Yan
   Huang, Yong (huangy@lcu.edu.cn) 
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 59
IS 6
PS 607-613
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species of free-living marine nematode of the genus Dorylaimopsis
   is described from the sublittoral sediment of the Jiaozhou Bay of
   Qingdao, China. Dorylaimopsis heteroapophysis sp. nov. is characterized
   by the cuticle punctuated in transverse lines with lateral
   differentiation of three longitudinal rows of larger dots in the
   pharyngeal and caudal regions and two longitudinal rows of larger dots
   in the rest of body. Labial sensilla very short. Four cephalic setae
   4-5.5 [mu]m long. Buccal cavity cylindrical with three cuticularised
   teeth. Amphideal fovea multi-spiral, 2.5-3 turns. Spicules arcuate,
   1.8-2 abd long, cephalated proximal end with short median cuticularized
   strip. Gubernaculum with two unequalsized dorso-caudally apophyses,
   right one short and left one longer. 11-12 fine tubular precloacal
   supplements. Tail conico-cylindrical with enlarged tip. An updated
   dichotomous key is provided for the 22 valid species of Dorylaimopsis.
C1 Huang, Yong; Liaocheng Univ, Coll Life Sci, Liaocheng, 252059, China,
   China.
EM huangy@lcu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0007-9723
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Dorylaimopsis heteroapophysis [North Pacific / China, Shandong / New
   species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Dorylaimopsis - Ditlevsen 1919 (Nematoda): [Key to species, Updated key,
   p. 611]. 
   Dorylaimopsis heteroapophysis (Nematoda): [Sp nov, China, Shandong
   (marine), P. 608].

DT Article
TI The taxonomic status of two species of predaceous midges in the genera
   Bezzia and Palpomyia described by STAEGER (1839) in the genus
   Ceratopogon (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae: Palpomyiini).
AU Dominiak, Patrycja (heliocopris@gmail.com) 
   Szadziewski, Ryszard
SO Dipteron - Wroclaw
VL 34
PS 94-108
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Lectotypes are designated for the predaceous midges, Ceratopogon
   circumdatus STAEGER, 1839, and Ceratopogon binotatus STAEGER, 1839
   housed in the Copenhagen Zoological Museum, Denmark, and both species
   are redescribed and photographed. Ceratopogon circumdatus is removed
   from synonymy with Bezzia solstitialis (WINNERTZ, 1852) and recognized
   as a new synonym of Bezzia annulipes (MEIGEN, 1830). Ceratopogon
   binotatus STAEGER, 1839, is removed from synonymy with Palpomyia lineata
   (MEIGEN, 1804) and recognized as the distinct species, Palpomyia
   binotata (STAEGER, 1839).
C1 Dominiak, Patrycja; UiT Arctic Univ Norway, Tromso Univ Museum, Tromso,
   NO-9037, Norway, Norway.
EM heliocopris@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1895-4464
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Description; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Palpomyiini [Denmark /  / Systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Ceratopogonidae
OR Bezzia annulipes - (Meigen 1830) (Ceratopogonidae): [Syn nov,
   Ceratopogon circumdatus Staeger 1939, p. 95]. 
   Bezzia solstitialis - Winnertz 1852 (Ceratopogonidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Ceratopogon circumdatus Staeger 1939, p. 96]. 
   Ceratopogon binotatus - Staeger 1939 (Ceratopogonidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 97; Removal from synonymy, With Palpomyia lineata Meigen
   1804, p. 97; Referred to, Palpomyia, p. 97].

TI Contribution to the knowledge of the oribatid mite genus Angullozetes
   (Acari: Oribatida: Scheloribatidae).
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Shtanchaeva, Umukusum Ya
   Subias, Luis S.
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 18
PS 75-81
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Angullozetes (Oribatida: Scheloribatidae) is
   described from New Zealand. Angullozetes. arilloi sp. nov. differs from
   the type species, A. rostratus Hammer, 1967 by the smaller body length,
   the presence of four pairs of notogastral porose areas and the absence
   of aggenital setae. A revised generic diagnosis of Angullozetes is
   presented.

   discusses classification of Saitis imitans, both species characterized
   by possession of a rare, three-chambered spermathecae. In the
   methodological layer paper is a test of the proposed new research
   protocol, including a shift to macrophotography of live specimens,
   whenever possible. New informal subgroup: SAITEAE Proszynski New genera:

   diminutus Edwards, 2003a: 71 = "Euophrys" diminuta (Banks, 1896) (see

PT J

DT Article
TI On the identity of Neritina baetica Lamarck, 1822 and Nerita
   meridionalis Philippi, 1836 (Gastropoda: Neritidae) from the Iberian
   Peninsula.
AU Gloeer, Peter (gloeer@malaco.de) 
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 18
PS 133-137
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB When Mermod (1953) depicted the types of Theodoxus baeticus of Lamarck's
   collection his photo did not display a pseudo-apophysis (peg). This led
   recent authors believe, that Th. baeticus is a synonym of Th.
   fluviatilis and Theodoxus meridionalis is the valid species (Alba et al.
   2016: 55). In this paper I studied the syntypes of Th. baeticus as well
   as the syntypes of Th. meridionalis and demonstrated that in Th.
   baeticus a pseudo-apophysis exists and the opercula of Th. baeticus and
   Th. meridionalis are similar. Thus Th. baeticus is a good species and
   Th. meridionalis is a younger synonym of it. Therefore I can conclude
   that three Theodoxus spp., i.e., Th. fluviatilis, Th. baeticus and Th.
   valentinus occur in the Iberian Peninsula.
C1 Gloeer, Peter; Biodivers Res Lab, Schulstr 3, Hetlingen, D-25491,
   Germany, Germany.
EM gloeer@malaco.de
SC Zoology
SN 2336-9744; 2336-9744
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia
DE Theodoxus baeticus; Theodoxus fluviatilis; Theodoxus valentinus [Europe
   / Iberian Peninsula / Distribution]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Archaeogastropoda,
   Neritoidea
OR Theodoxus baeticus - (Lamarck 1822) (Neritoidea): [Syn nov, Theodoxus
   meridionalis (Philippi 1836), p. 136; Removal from synonymy, With
   Theodoxus fluviatilis (Linnaeus 1758), p. 134]. 
   Theodoxus fluviatilis - (Linnaeus 1758) (Neritoidea): [Removal from
   synonymy, Theodoxus baeticus (Lamarck 1822), p. 134]. 
   Theodoxus valentinus (Neritoidea). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15504019501
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17
ER

TI The distribution of Adrastus circassicus (Coleoptera: Elateridae).
FT Rozsireni druhu Adrastus circassicus (Coleoptera: Elateridae).
AU Mertlik, Josef (mertlik@elateridae.com) 
SO Elateridarium
VL 12
PS 7-17
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA Czech
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper, I summarize the distribution records of Adrastus
   circassicus Reitter, 1896 from the Caucasus, Turkey, Czech Republic, and
   for the first time from Poland. The biotopes of this click-beetle
   species are described in detail and photo-documented. The website
   photogallery containing 70 photographs of the biotopes serves as a
   supplement of this paper. Adrastus juditae Laibner, 1991 is synonymized
   with Adrastus circassicus Reitter, 1896.

AN ZOOR15504019423
DT Article
TI CONTRIBUTION TO THE MICROLEPIDOPTERA FAUNA OF THE SOUTH OF THE
   KRASNOYARSK TERRITORY AND THE REPUBLIC OF KHAKASSIA.
AU Akulov, E.N. (akulich80@ya.ru) 
   Kirichenko, N.I.
   Ponomarenko, M.G.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 97
IS 1
PS 110-146
PD 2018
PY 2018
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 2
AB This paper provides a list of 125 species of Microlepidoptera from 22
   families collected in the south of the Krasnoyarsk Territory and in the
   Republic of Khakassia, with 63 species (50 %) and 2 families
   (Bucculatricidae and Elachistidae) recorded in the region for the first
   time. 11 species from 6 families are new to Siberia: Cauchas fibulella,
   Nemophora fasciella, N. minimella (Adelidae), Phyllonorycter sorbicola,
   Phyllocnistis extrematrix (Gracillariidae), Cosmiotes freyerella,
   Elachista subocellea (Elachistidae), Caryocolum alsinella, Scrobipalpula
   diffluella (Gelechiidae), Agonopterix intersecta (Depressariidae) and
   Ypsolopha horridella (Ypsolophidae). Three species: Phyllonorycter sp.
   and Phyllocnistis verae (Gracillariidae) from the suburbs of Krasnoyarsk
   and Chrysoesthia sp. (Gelechiidae) from the Republic of Khakassia are
   new to science. Almost half of the faunistic findings belong to the two
   families, Gelechiidae (34 species) and Gracillariidae (24 species). In
   the former family, the number of species distributed in Krasnoyarsk
   Territory and / or the Republic of Khakassia was increased by 1.5 times
   based on our collection. Among the 125 species, the trophic
   specialization remains unknown only for 7 species. Of the 118 species,
   the majority (90 %) are phytophagous species, others are saprophagous.
   53 species are known as leaf miners. Phytophagous species feed on plants
   of 36 botanical families and 21 orders. The largest number of
   microlepidopteran species inhabits the plants of the orders of Rosales
   and Fagales (25 and 24 species respectively). Twelve species are known
   as pests: Tineidae (4 species), Gracillariidae, Gelechiidae (2 species
   in each), Argyresthiidae, Choreutidae, Lyonetiidae and Plutellidae (one
   species in each). Four pest species Choreutis pariana (Choreutidae),
   Scrobipalpa atriplicella (Gelechiidae), Plutella xylostella
   (Plutellidae) and Niditinea fuscella (Tineidae) have distributed beyond
   the Palaearctic in the last century.
C1 Akulov, E.N.; Krasnoyarsk Branch, All Russian Ctr Plant Quarantine,
   Maerchaka Str 31A, Krasnoyarsk, 660075, Russia, Russia.
EM akulich80@ya.ru
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 0367-1445
BD Documentation; Publications; Nutrition; Diet; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia
DE Microlepidoptera [Checklists / Annotated checklist of species / plant
   list] [Food plants /  / ] [Russia / Krasnoyarsk & Khakassia / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera
OR Microlepidoptera (Lepidoptera).

AB A new species Eurytoma koreana Zerova et Fursov, sp. n. is described
   from South Korea. The new species is close to Eurytoma verticillata

TI NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS ADOXOMYIA KERTESZ, 1907 (DIPTERA,
   STRATIOMYIDAE) WITH BLACK ANTENNAE.
AU Krivosheina, N.P. (dipteranina@rambler.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 97
IS 1
PS 156-169
PD 2018
PY 2018
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Adoxomyia Kertesz, 1907, Adoxomyia smirnovi
   sp. n. H A. sublugubris sp. n., are described from Uzbekistan and
   Tadzhikistan. Extended descriptions of the closely related to these
   species A. alaschanica Pleske, 1925, A. lugubris Pleske, 1925, and A.
   obscuripennis (Loew, 1873) are given. Adoxomyia smirnovi sp. n. differs
   from the close A. alaschanica in the short black spines on the scutellum
   and in the structure of the male genitalia with a narrow sclerotized
   projection of the synsternum. Adoxomyia sublugubris sp. n. differs from
   the closely allied A. lugubris in the light knob of the haltere and very
   long spines on the scutellum. A key to the 5 species is composed.

   Moscow, 119071, Russia, Russia.

PY 2018
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new Palaearctic genus Neopsilocurus gen. n. is erected for Psilocurus
   negrus Lehr, 1974 (type species) and Ps. hypopygialis (Paramonov, 1930).
   A detailed comparative characteristic of the two Neopsilocurus species
   is given with descriptions of the external structure and photographs of
   the male genitalia. A key to species of the new genus is compiled based
   on the original and literature data.
C1 Astakhov, D.M.; Volgograd State Univ, Univ Ave,100, Volgograd, 100,
   Russia, Russia.
EM dmitriy_astachov@mail.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0367-1445

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key

   Asilidae

   species Psilocurus negrus Lehr 1974, p. 171; Key to species, P. 172]. 
   Neopsilocurus hypopygialis - (Paramonov 1930) (Asilidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Psilocurus, p. 172]. 
   Neopsilocurus negrus - (Lehr 1974) (Asilidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Psilocurus, p. 173].

DT Article
TI On the Trichoptera of Batanta Island (Indonesia, Papua, Raja Ampat
   Archipelago) VI.
AU Olah, Janos (profolah@gmail.com) 
   Kovacs, Tibor
SO Folia Historico Naturalia Musei Matraensis
VL 42
PS 163-195
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper, the sixth in the Batanta Island series on Trichoptera,
   presents new species records and describes new species in the families
   of Phi lopotamidae: Chimarra parza Olah sp. n.; Dipseudopsidac;
   Ecnomidae: Ecnomus fiak Olah sp. n., Ecnomus vajtos Olah sp. n.;
   Psychomyiidae: Tinodes savos Olah sp. n., Tinodes simul Olah sp. n.;
   Polycentropodidae: Nyctiophylax (Paranyctiophylax) sotet Olah sp. n.;
   Hydropsychidae: Abacaria kevera Olah sp. n.; Glossosomatidae: Agapetus
   perem Olah sp. n.; Hydroptilidae: Hydroptila batanta Olah sp. n.,
   Ugandatrichia batanta Olah sp. n., Orthotrichia fosla Olah sp. n.,
   Orthotrichia holaga Olah sp. n., Niuginitrichia harmas Olah sp. n.,
   Niuginitrichia homora Milt sp. n., Niuginitrichia vagva Olah sp. n.,
   Pseudoxyethira egba Olah sp. n.; Calamoceratidae: Anisocentropus
   arfakensis Olah sp. n., Anisocentropus batantensis Olah sp. n.,
   Anisocentropus susannae Olah et Kovacs sp. n. Triplectides sugaras Olah
   2014 is considered a junior synonym of Triplectides dombos Olah, 2014,
   syn. n. and the erroneously associated female paratype of Triplectides
   dombos represents an undescribed species.

DT Article
TI Parasites of the Spotted Sucker, Minytrema melanops (Cypriniformes:
   Catostomidae) from Arkansas and Oklahoma.
AU McAllister, C.T. (cmcallister@se.edu) 
   Cloutman, D.G.
   Choudhury, A.
   Scholz, T.
   Trauth, S.E.
   Fayton, T.J.
   Robison, H.W.
SO Journal of the Arkansas Academy of Science
VL 72
PS 87-93
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During October 2015, March and April 2016 and again between March and
   April 2017, 15 Spotted Sucker (Minytrema melanops) were collected from
   sites in the Ouachita (n = 5), Red (n = 1), and St. Francis (n = 5)
   river drainages, Arkansas, and the Arkansas River drainage, Oklahoma (n
   = 4), and examined for protozoan and metazoan parasites. Found were
   Calyptospora sp., Myxobolus sp., Pseudomurraytrema alabarrum,
   Biacetabulum banghami, Penarchigetes oklensis, and Acanthocephalus sp.
   New host and distributional records are documented for these parasites.
C1 McAllister, C.T.; Eastern Oklahoma State Coll, Div Sci & Math, Idabel,
   OK, 74745, USA, USA.
EM cmcallister@se.edu
SC Parasitology; Zoology
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA

   Minytrema melanops / Prevalence] [Arkansas / Ouachita & St. Francis
   river drainages / ] [ /  / New record] [Oklahoma / Arkansas River
   drainage / ]. 
   Calyptospora [Piscean hosts / Minytrema melanops / New record] [ /  /
   Prevalence] [Arkansas /  / ] [ / Ouachita & St. Francis river drainages
   / ] [Oklahoma / Arkansas River drainage / ]. 
   Minytrema melanops [Acanthocephalan parasites / Neoechinorhynchus / New
   record] [ /  / Prevalence] [Cestode parasites / Biacetabulum banghami /
   ] [ / Penarchigetes oklensis / ] [Monogenean parasites /
   Pseudomurraytrema alabarrum / ] [Myxozoan parasites / Myxobolus / ]
   [Protozoan parasites / Calyptospora / ] [ /  / ] [Arkansas /  / ] [ /  /
   ] [ / Ouachita & St. Francis river drainages / ] [Oklahoma /  / ] [ /
   Arkansas River drainage / ]. 
   Myxobolus; Penarchigetes oklensis [Piscean hosts / Minytrema melanops /
   Prevalence] [Arkansas / Ouachita & St. Francis river drainages / ]
   [Oklahoma / Arkansas River drainage / ]. 
   Neoechinorhynchus [Piscean hosts / Minytrema melanops / New record] [ / 
   / Prevalence] [Arkansas /  / ] [ / Ouachita & St. Francis river
   drainages / ] [Oklahoma /  / ] [ / Arkansas River drainage / ].

DT Article
TI The Turtles from the Middle Eocene sediments of Eckfeld Maar with
   taxonomic notes on Testudo eocaenica HUMMEL, 1935 (Middle Eocene,
   Germany, Rhineland-Palatinate, Vulkaneifel).
FT Die Schildkroten aus den Mitteleozanen Sedimenten des Eckfelder Maares
   mit taxonomischen Notizen zu Testudo eocaenica HUMMEL, 1935
   (Mitteleozan, Deutschland, Rheinland-Pfalz, Vulkaneifel).
AU Karl, Hans-Volker (hvkarl@icloud.com) 
SO Mainzer Naturwissenschaftliches Archiv
VL 55
PS 61-95
PD 2018
PY 2018
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB From middle Eocene maar sediments of Eckfeld the softshell turtle
   Rafetoides messelianus, the snapping turtle Chelydrasia decheni, the
   pond turtles Palaeoemys germanica, Borkenia eckfeldense n. sp. and
   Borkenia philippeni n. sp., the terrestrial hinge turtle Geiselemys
   ptychogastroides and the large land tortoise Barnesia eocaenica n. comb.
   are recorded. Palaeoamyda CADENA, 2016 is a junior synonym to
   Rafetoides. Barnesia n. gen. is a new genus name for Testudo eocaenica
   HUMMEL, 1935 and Eochersina n. gen., a new genus name for Cheirogaster
   steinbacherae (KARL, 1996). The authentic specimens of Testudo ecoenica
   from the Geiseltal are redefined and described in comparison to the
   Eckfeld material and the Eocene Basic Testudinidae, Cheirogaster
   sharanensis n. comb. and Cheirogaster kaiseni n. comb. are new taxonomic
   allocations.
C1 Karl, Hans-Volker; Friedrich Schiller Univ Jena, Seminar Ur &
   Fruhgeschichtl Archaol, Lobdergraben 24a, Jena, D-07743, Germany,
   Germany.
EM hvkarl@icloud.com
SC Zoology
SN 0542-1535

   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene

   for new genus, Barnesia, p. 77]. 
   Titanochelon steinbacheri - (Karl 1996) (Testudinidae): [Referred to,
   Eochersina, p. 84]. 
   Rafetoides - Karl 1998 (Trionychidae): [Syn nov, Palaeoamyda Cadena
   2016, p. 67]. 
   Rafetoides messelianus - (Reinach 1900) (Trionychidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Trionyx, p. 67]. 
   Trionyx messelianus - Reinach 1900 (Trionychidae): [Referred to,
   Rafetoides, p. 67].
